document_title: Wrist bursitis: Causes, signs and treatments
subsection_name: viem-bao-hoat-dich-co-tay.json_5_Will this condition go away on its own?
subsection_content:
Depending on the cause, inflammation can resolve on its own within a few weeks, with home treatments combined with adjustments to daily habits, specifically: (4)
Apply hot and cold compresses properly.; Give your wrists time to rest after performing exercises and repetitive wrist activities. Patients should only continue these activities when pain and swelling are controlled.; Minimize activities that put stress on your wrists such as writing, typing, gardening, playing musical instruments, lifting weights, playing volleyball, basketball, etc. Only return to these activities when you have good pain control. and swelling.; Use assistive devices such as lid openers, key turners, and large lock pullers; use utensils and kitchen utensils with large handles.; Replace doors with knobs with doors with lever handles.; Wear a wrist brace or gloves to support your wrist while sleeping or performing repetitive movements during the day.
Besides applying home care measures, patients also need to pay attention to their daily menu. Providing the body with enough vitamins and minerals will greatly support the recovery process and prevent the risk of recurrence. Foods that patients with wrist bursitis should add to their daily meals include:
Green vegetables: This food group contains abundant antioxidants and anti-inflammatories, which are very good for the recovery process. You can supplement foods such as spinach, kale, carrots, pumpkin,...; Fruits such as apples, grapes, blueberries, raspberries, raspberries, strawberries, papaya, pineapple... are all good sources of powerful anti-inflammatory ingredients such as vitamins A and D.; Nuts and beans such as green beans, red beans, walnuts, almonds, pistachios, macadamia nuts...; Fresh fruit juices and green tea.
In addition, people with wrist synovitis should also limit consumption of foods such as:
Foods rich in omega-6 such as mayonnaise, peanuts, soybeans...; Foods with high gluten content such as rye, wheat...; Dishes that are too sugary, salty, greasy, and alcoholic drinks such as wine, beer, etc.
